DOC.HEAD: Marshals Screening Packages Mailed to Courthouses After Mail-Bombings
Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, Employees were, with pen set found in suspicious package
DOC.TEXT: Federal marshals examined packages delivered to U.S. courthouses and officials briefly evacuated a Justice Department corridor today in the wake of mail-bomb killings of an appellate judge in Alabama and a lawyer in Savannah, Ga. The nation's federal judges were advised to let the U.S. marshals inspect any package mailed to their chambers, even those bearing a familiar return address. Judges were told ``to bring all packages to the attention of the marshals so they can be screened and X-rayed before opening,'' said William Dempsey, a spokesman for the Marshals Service in Washington. The advisory also applies to packages bearing familiar names because ``return addresses can be forged or faked,'' Dempsey said. At the Justice Department, security officials briefly evacuated offices along a section of a first-floor corridor when a suspicious package addressed to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh turned up in the basement mailroom, officials said. Employees were allowed to return to their offices 10 minutes later after officials determined the parcel was not dangerous. After X-raying the package, security officials determined it contained a pen set for the attorney general, said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel. ``We're being more vigilant,'' said Flavio Lorenzoni, Chief Deputy U.S. Marshal for the Southern District of New York. ``All packages are being checked carefully.'' Lorenzoni, like colleagues elsewhere across the country, declined to discuss specific security precautions taken since the assassination of Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance, who was killed Saturday by a package bomb sent to his home outside Birmingham, Ala. Authorities also were investigating a mailed bomb that killed Savannah, Ga., attorney Robert Robinson, who was a city alderman and black civil rights activist. Robinson died Monday night after undergoing emergency surgery for injuries he received in the blast in his office several hours earlier, officials said. Just as security was being redoubled Monday at many federal courthouses across the country, another package bomb turned up at the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. The bomb was found in a package during a screening of mail sent to the courthouse, which is the headquarters of the 11th Circuit, on which Vance sat. In Miami, Chief Deputy U.S. Marshal James Tassone said packages and mail entering the federal courthouses in that city as well as in Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach were being X-rayed. Extra inspections of people entering the courthouses also were being conducted by guards, he said. Some courthouse employees were asked to empty their pockets as they passed through metal detectors. Officials in other courthouses reported that security was already tight and didn't need to be upgraded. But Deputy Marshal Jeff Whitney in Evansville, Ind., said judges were instructed not to open any uninspected packages. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush discussed the Vance assassination with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who reported that investigators ``have not reached any conclusions'' about the case. ``We just don't have any answers yet as to who might have done it to him,'' Fitzwater said.
